sentences: )I want to say thank you to the Thunder for hosting us here today.
label: true_

sentences: I want you to give it up for somebody who’s been fighting for homeowners and working families every single day, who’s with me today -- Secretary Shaun Donovan, Secretary of HUD.
label: true_

sentences: Give him a big round of applause.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got Congressman Ed Pastor who’s here as well.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve got your Mayor, Greg Stanton, here.
label: true_

sentences: Doing an outstanding job.
label: true_

sentences: And to all the mayors and state legislators and tribal leaders who are here today, thank you.
label: true_

sentences: )Give Jorge a big round of applause for his introduction.
label: true_

sentences: To your superintendent, Dr. Kenneth Baca.
label: true_

sentences: Your principal, Dr. Anna Battle.
label: true_

sentences: And I appreciate everybody at Desert Vista for having me here today.
label: true_

sentences: It is good to see the students are pretty enthusiastic about being back in school.
label: true_

sentences: I’m not sure I would have been that enthusiastic starting on the 6th.
label: true_

sentences: )And I know this isn’t your typical school -- second day of school.
label: true_

sentences: So I want to give a special shout-out to the new seniors, class of 2014.
label: true_

sentences: You are aware that you’re not finished yet.
label: true_

sentences: Senior year, that’s sometimes tempting.
label: true_

sentences: I want you all to stay focused.Over the past couple weeks, I have been --AUDIENCE MEMBER: Happy birthday, Mr. President!THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much.
label: true_

sentences: It was my birthday two days ago.
label: true_

sentences: Got some singers here.AUDIENCE: Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you, happy birthday, Mr. President.
label: true_

sentences: )THE PRESIDENT: Thank you.
label: true_

sentences: I am now 52, and Michelle says that I don’t look a day over 51.
label: true_

sentences: )So over the last few weeks, I’ve been visiting towns all across the country, talking about what we need to do to secure a better bargain for the middle class -- a national strategy to make sure that everybody who works hard has a chance to succeed in the 21st century economy.And I think people in Arizona especially understand the challenges that are out there, because for the past four and a half years, together, we fought our way back from a devastating recession that cost millions of jobs for Americans.
label: true_

sentences: A lot of folks lost their homes; a lot of folks lost their savings.
label: true_

sentences: And what the recession showed was the long erosion of middle-class security that had been taking place for decades.But we fought back.
label: true_

sentences: We took on a broken health care system.
label: true_

sentences: We took on a housing market that was in free fall.
label: true_

sentences: We invested in new technologies to reverse our addiction to foreign oil.
label: true_

sentences: We changed a tax code that had become tilted a little bit too much in favor of the wealthiest Americans at the expense of working families.
label: true_

sentences: We saved the auto industry.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve now got GM that plans to hire a thousand new workers right next door in Chandler to make sure we’re building some of the best cars in the world right here in the United States of America.
label: true_

sentences: )Our businesses have created 7.3 million new jobs over the past 41 months.
label: true_

sentences: We now sell more products made in America to the rest of the world than ever before.
label: true_

sentences: Our exports are way up.
label: true_

sentences: We produce more renewable energy than ever before, more natural gas than anybody else.
label: true_

sentences: Health care costs have been growing at the slowest rate in 50 years.
label: true_

sentences: And our deficits are coming down at the fastest rate in 60 years.
label: true_

sentences: So we’re making progress.
label: true_

sentences: )So thanks to the efforts of a lot of people like you, we’ve cleared away the rubble of the financial crisis.
label: true_

sentences: We’re starting to lay the foundation for more stable, more durable economic growth.
label: true_

sentences: But as any middle-class family will tell you, we’re not yet where we need to be.
label: true_

sentences: Because even before the crisis hit, we had lived through a decade where a few at the top were doing better and better, but most families were working harder and harder just to get by.And reversing this trend should be -- must be -- Washington’s highest priority.
label: true_

sentences: It’s my highest priority.
label: true_

sentences: I want to make sure that in America, it doesn’t matter what you look like, where you come from, who you love -- you should be able to make it when you try.
label: true_

sentences: You should be able to make it.
label: true_

sentences: )Now, unfortunately, for the last year or so, we’ve had an endless parade of distractions and political posturing and phony scandals that shift focus away from what do we need to do to shore up middle-class families and create ladders of opportunity for folks to get into the middle class.
label: true_

sentences: And as Washington heads towards another budget debate, the stakes could not be higher.And that’s why I’m traveling around, laying out my ideas for how we have to build the cornerstones of what it means to be middle class: a good job with good wages; a home to call your own; a good education; affordable health care that’s there for you when you get sick; a secure retirement even if you’re not rich; the opportunity -- the ladders of opportunity for people to earn their way into the middle class, to work their way out of poverty.
label: true_

sentences: Those are the elements that I think all of us believe in, but right now we're not delivering as much as we should on those promises.Now, last Tuesday, I went to Tennessee to talk about the first cornerstone, which is how do we make sure that we're creating good middle-class jobs here in the United States of America.
label: true_

sentences: Today I've come to Phoenix to talk about the second component, which is the most tangible cornerstone that lies at the heart of the American Dream, at the heart of middle-class life -- and that's the chance to own your own home.
label: true_

sentences: The chance to own your own home.We've got a lot of young people here who are thinking about college, they're going to get a higher education, they're going to find a job, they're going to find somebody they love, they're going to want to own a home.
label: true_

sentences: And the reason they will is because a home is the ultimate evidence that here in America, hard work pays off, that responsibility is rewarded.I think about my grandparents’ generation.
label: true_

sentences: When my grandfather served in World War II, he fought in Patton's Army -- when he got back, this country gave him a chance to go to college on the G.I.
label: true_

sentences: Bill, but it also gave him the chance to buy his first home with a loan from the FHA.
label: true_

sentences: To him, and to generations of Americans before and since, a home was more than just a house.
label: true_

sentences: It was a source of pride and a source of security.
label: true_

sentences: It was a place to raise kids, to put down roots; a place where you could build up savings for college, or to start a business, or to retire with some security.And buying a home required responsibility on everybody’s part.
label: true_

sentences: You had to save up to buy a home.
label: true_

sentences: And then banks were supposed to give you a fair deal, with terms you could understand, and buyers were supposed to live within their means and make sure that they could make their payments.
label: true_

sentences: So in that earlier generation, houses weren’t for flipping around, they weren’t for speculation -- houses were to live in, and to build a life with.And unfortunately, over time, responsibility too often gave way to recklessness.
label: true_

sentences: You had reckless lenders who sold loans to people they knew couldn’t afford them.
label: true_

sentences: And let's face it, we also had some reckless buyers who knew they couldn’t afford them and still took out loans.
label: true_

sentences: And all this created a housing bubble.
label: true_

sentences: And especially in some places like Arizona, it was devastating when that bubble finally burst -- triggered a recession.
label: true_

sentences: Millions of Americans who had done everything right were hurt badly by the actions of other people.
label: true_

sentences: Housing prices plummeted.By the time I took office, home values had fallen almost 20 percent from the year before.
label: true_

sentences: New housing starts had fallen nearly 80 percent from their peak.
label: true_

sentences: Hundreds of thousands of construction workers had lost their jobs.
label: true_

sentences: A record number of people were behind on their mortgage payments.
label: true_

sentences: And a lot of people here in Phoenix, they saw that devastation.
label: true_

sentences: This was part of Ground Zero for the housing bubble bursting.So less than a month after I took office, I came here to Arizona and I laid out steps to stabilize the housing market and help responsible homeowners get back on their feet.
label: true_

sentences: And the truth is it's been a long, slow process.
label: true_

sentences: The housing market is so big that it was going to take some time to heal when it got hurt that badly.
label: true_

sentences: It's taken longer than any of us would like.
label: true_

sentences: But during that time, we helped millions of Americans save an average of $3,000 each year by refinancing at lower rates.
label: true_

sentences: We helped millions of responsible homeowners stay in their homes, which was good for their neighbors because you don't want a bunch of foreclosure signs in your neighborhood.Where Congress wouldn’t act, we went ahead and acted, so over the past few years, we had the Department of Justice stand up for buyers who had been discriminated against or conned by predatory lending.
label: true_

sentences: And we won a settlement that gave more money to victims of discrimination in one year than in the previous 23 years combined.
label: true_

sentences: )We worked with states to force big banks to repay more than $50 billion to more than 1.5 million families -- largest lending settlement in history.
label: true_

sentences: We extended the time that folks who had lost their jobs could delay their payment on their mortgages while they kept looking for work.
label: true_

sentences: We cracked down on the bad practices that led to the crisis in the first place.
label: true_

sentences: I mean, you had some loans back there in the bubble that were called “liar’s loan.” Now, something that's called a liar's loan is probably a bad idea.
label: true_

sentences: )So because of all these actions we've been taking, our housing market is beginning to heal.
label: true_

sentences: Home prices are rising at the fastest pace in seven years.
label: true_

sentences: Sales are up nearly 50 percent.
label: true_

sentences: Construction is up nearly 75 percent.
label: true_

sentences: New foreclosures are down by nearly two-thirds.
label: true_

sentences: Millions of families have been able to come up for air -- they’re no longer underwater on their mortgages.
label: true_

sentences: )And just like the crisis hit Phoenix very hard, thanks to some great leadership here locally, Phoenix has also led one of the biggest comebacks in the country.
label: true_

sentences: So you should be proud of what you've done here.
label: true_

sentences: Home prices in Phoenix have risen by nearly 20 percent over the last year.
label: true_

sentences: New home sales are up by more than 25 percent.This morning, right before I came here, I visited Erickson Construction -- (applause.)
label: true_

sentences: We've got some Erickson folks here.
label: true_

sentences: And they were explaining how right when the bubble hit, Erickson shrank to less than a hundred workers.
label: true_

sentences: Today they're employing 580 people -- and they’re hiring even more people -- (applause) -- because the housing market is bouncing back.So that's one of the things about housing.
label: true_

sentences: It's not just important for the person who owns the house; our economy is so impacted by everything that happens in housing.
label: true_

sentences: Consumers feel better when their home values are in a better place, so they're more willing to spend.
label: true_

sentences: A lot of people who want to start a business, their savings may be locked up in their house.
label: true_

sentences: Construction workers, contractors, suppliers, carpet makers, all these folks are impacted by the housing industry.So we've made progress, and that's helped to move the economy forward.
label: true_

sentences: But we've got to build on this progress.
label: true_

sentences: We're not where we need to be yet.
label: true_

sentences: We've got to give more hardworking Americans the chance to buy their first home.
label: true_

sentences: We have to help more responsible homeowners refinance their mortgages, because a lot of them still have a spread between the rates they're paying right now on their mortgage and what they could be getting if they were able to refinance.And we’ve got to turn the page on this kind of bubble-and-bust mentality that helped to create this mess in the first place.
label: true_

sentences: We got to build a housing system that is durable and fair and rewards responsibility for generations to come.
label: true_

sentences: That's what we’ve got to do.
label: true_

sentences: )So I’ve already put forward a bunch of ideas that will help accomplish that.
label: true_

sentences: And, look, the fact of the matter is Congress hasn’t enacted all of them, so I’d like you to encourage members of Congress to take some of these actions.
label: true_

sentences: )But like the other actions that we’ve taken, these will not help the neighbors down the street who bought a house that they couldn’t afford, and then walked away from it and left a foreclosed home behind.
label: true_

sentences: We don't want to help speculators who bought multiple homes just to make a quick buck.What we want to do is put forward ideas that will help millions of responsible, middle-class homeowners who still need relief.
label: true_

sentences: And we want to help hardworking Americans who dream of owning their own home fair and square, have a down payment, are willing to make those payments, understand that owning a home requires responsibility.
label: true_

sentences: And there are some immediate actions we could take right now that would help on that front, that would make a difference.
label: true_

sentences: So let me just list a couple of them.Number one: Congress should pass a good, bipartisan idea to allow every homeowner the chance to save thousands of dollars a year by refinancing their mortgage at today’s rates.
label: true_

sentences: We need to get that done.
label: true_

sentences: We’ve been talking about it for a year and a half, two years, three years.
label: true_

sentences: There’s no reason not to do it.
label: true_

sentences: )Step number two: Now that we’ve made it harder for reckless buyers to buy homes that they can’t afford, let’s make it a little bit easier for qualified buyers to buy the homes that they can afford.
label: true_

sentences: So Shaun Donovan has been working with the finance industry to make sure we’re simplifying overlapping regulations; we’re cutting red tape for responsible families who want to get a mortgage but keep getting rejected by the banks.
label: true_

sentences: We need to give well-qualified Americans who lost their jobs during the crisis a fair chance to get a loan if they’ve worked hard to repair their credit.And step three is something that you don’t always hear about when it comes to the housing market, and that is fixing our broken immigration system.
label: true_

sentences: It would actually help our housing market.
label: true_

sentences: )It’s pretty simple: When more people buy homes and play by the rules, home values go up for everybody.
label: true_

sentences: And according to one recent study, the average homeowner has already seen the value of their home boosted by thousands of dollars just because of immigration.
label: true_

sentences: And the good news is, with the help of your Senators, John McCain and Jeff Flake, the Senate has already passed a bipartisan immigration bill.
label: true_

sentences: It’s got the support of CEOs and labor and law enforcement.
label: true_

sentences: This could help homeownership here.So I want you to encourage Republicans in the House of Representatives to stop dragging their feet.
label: true_

sentences: Let’s go ahead and get this done.Step number four: We should address the uneven recovery by rebuilding the communities hit the hardest by the housing crisis, including many right here in Arizona.
label: true_

sentences: Let’s put construction back -- construction workers back to work repairing rundown homes, tearing down vacant properties so that the value of homes in those surrounding areas start picking up.
label: true_

sentences: We can put people to work right now and improve the remaining housing stock that's out there.
label: true_

sentences: Places that are facing a longer road back from the crisis should have their country’s help to get back on their feet.Step five: We should make sure families that don’t want to buy a home or can’t yet afford to buy one still have a decent place to rent.
label: true_

sentences: It’s important for us to encourage homeownership, but a lot of people rent and there’s nothing wrong with renting.
label: true_

sentences: And we got to make sure that we are creating affordable opportunities when it comes to rental properties.In the run-up to the crisis, banks and governments too often made everybody feel like they had to own a home, even if they weren’t ready and didn't have the payments.
label: true_

sentences: That’s a mistake we should not repeat.
label: true_

sentences: Instead, let’s invest in affordable rental housing.
label: true_

sentences: Let’s bring together cities and states to address local barriers that drive up rents for working families.
label: true_

sentences: )So if we help more Americans refinance their homes, if we help qualified families get a mortgage, we reform our immigration system, we rebuild the hardest-hit communities, we make sure that folks have a decent place to rent if they're not yet able to buy -- all these steps will give more middle-class families the chance to either buy their own home now or eventually buy their own home.
label: true_

sentences: It's going to give more relief to responsible homeowners.
label: true_

sentences: It gives more options to families who aren’t yet ready to buy.
label: true_

sentences: All that is going to improve the housing market and will improve the economy.But -- and this is the last key point I want to make -- as home prices rise, we can’t just re-inflate another housing bubble.
label: true_

sentences: I hope everybody here in Arizona learned some hard lessons from what happened.
label: true_

sentences: Housing prices generally don't just keep on going up forever at the kind of pace it was going up.
label: true_

sentences: It was crazy.
label: true_

sentences: So what we want to do is something stable and steady.
label: true_

sentences: And that's why I want to lay a rock-solid foundation to make sure the kind of crisis we went through never happens again.
label: true_

sentences: We've got to make sure it doesn't happen again.
label: true_

sentences: )And one of the key things to make sure it doesn't happen again is to wind down these companies that are not really government, but not really private sector -- they're known as Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.
label: true_

sentences: For too long, these companies were allowed to make huge profits buying mortgages, knowing that if their bets went bad, taxpayers would be left holding the bag.
label: true_

sentences: It was “heads we win, tails you lose.” And it was wrong.
label: true_

sentences: And along with what happened on Wall Street, it helped to inflate this bubble in a way that ultimately killed Main Street.So the good news is, right now there’s a bipartisan group of senators working to end Fannie and Freddie as we know them.
label: true_

sentences: And I support these kinds of reform efforts.
label: true_

sentences: And they're following four core principles for what I believe this reform should look like.First, private capital should take a bigger role in the mortgage market.
label: true_

sentences: I know that sounds confusing to folks who call me a socialist -- I think I saw some posters there on the way in.
label: true_

sentences: But I actually believe in the free market.
label: true_

sentences: And just like the health care law that we put in place, Obamacare -- (applause) -- which, by the way, if you don't have health insurance or you're buying it at exorbitant rates on the individual market, starting on October 1st, you can join a marketplace and be part of a pool that gives you much lower premiums, saves you a lot of money.
label: true_

sentences: )But in the same way that what we did with health care was to set up clear rules for insurance companies to protect consumers, make it more affordable, but still built on the private marketplace, I believe that our housing system should operate where there's a limited government role and private lending should be the backbone of the housing market.
label: true_

sentences: And that includes, by the way, community-based lenders who view their borrowers not as a number, but as a neighbor.
label: true_

sentences: So that's one principle.A second principle is we can't leave taxpayers on the hook for irresponsibility or bad decisions by some of these lenders or Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac.
label: true_

sentences: We've got to encourage the pursuit of profit, but the era of expecting a bailout after you pursue your profit and you don't manage your risk well -- well, that puts the whole country at risk.
label: true_

sentences: And we're ending those days.
label: true_

sentences: We're not going to do that anymore.
label: true_

sentences: )The third principle is we should preserve access to safe and simple mortgage products like the 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage.
label: true_

sentences: That’s something families should be able to rely on when they're making the most important purchase of their lives.
label: true_

sentences: )Number four, we've got to keep housing affordable for first-time homebuyers -- like all these young people.
label: true_

sentences: When they're ready to buy a house, we've got to make sure it's affordable.
label: true_

sentences: Families who are working to climb their way into the middle class, we've got to do what we can to make housing affordable.
label: true_

sentences: And that means we've got to strengthen the FHA so it gives today’s families the same kind of chance it gave my grandparents to buy a home, and it preserves those rungs on the ladder of opportunity.And we've got to support, as I said, affordable rental housing.
label: true_

sentences: And, by the way, we've also got to keep up our fight against homelessness.
label: true_

sentences: The Mayor of Phoenix has been doing a great job here in Phoenix on that front.
label: true_

sentences: We've got to continue to improve it.
label: true_

sentences: )Since I took office, we helped bring one in four homeless veterans off the streets.
label: true_

sentences: We should be proud of that.
label: true_

sentences: Here in Phoenix, thanks to the hard work of everyone from Mayor Stanton to the local United Way to US Airways, you’re on track to end chronic homelessness for veterans, period, by 2014.
label: true_

sentences: (Applause.
label: true_

sentences: )But we've got to keep going, because nobody in America, and certainly no veteran, should be left to live on the streets.
label: true_

sentences: )So here's the bottom line: Put all these principles together, that's going to protect our entire economy and it will improve the housing market not just here in Phoenix, but throughout the state and throughout the country.We're also going to need to make sure, though, that we're protecting individual homeowners.
label: true_

sentences: We've got to give them the tools that they can protect themselves.
label: true_

sentences: So we've got a Consumer Finance Protection Bureau that we created.
label: true_

sentences: And it's laying down new rules of the road that everybody can count on when they’re shopping for a mortgage.
label: true_

sentences: They’re designing a new, simple mortgage form that will be in plain English, so you can actually read it without a lawyer -- (applause) -- although, you may still want a lawyer obviously.
label: true_

sentences: I'm not saying you don't.
label: true_

sentences: I'm just saying you'll be able to read it.
label: true_

sentences: There won't be a lot of fine print.
label: true_

sentences: That way you know before you owe.
label: true_

sentences: (Laughter and applause.
label: true_

sentences: )And the Senate finally confirmed Richard Cordray as the head of this -- head watchdog for the CFPB.
label: true_

sentences: So he's out there aggressively protecting consumers and homeowners.When it comes to some of the other leaders we need to look out for the American people, the Senate still has a job to do.
label: true_

sentences: Months ago, I nominated a man named Mel Watt to be our nation’s top housing regulator.
label: true_

sentences: He is an outstanding member of Congress.
label: true_

sentences: And during that time, he was on the Housing Committee -- worked with banks, worked with borrowers to protect consumers, to help responsible lenders provide credit.
label: true_

sentences: He is the right person for the job.
label: true_

sentences: Congress and the Senate should give his nomination an up or down vote without any more obstruction or delay.
label: true_

sentences: We don't have time for those kinds of games.
label: true_

sentences: )So I want to be honest with you.
label: true_

sentences: No program or policy is going to solve all the problems in a multi-trillion dollar housing market.
label: true_

sentences: The housing bubble went up so high, the heights it reached before it burst were so unsustainable, that we knew it was going to take some time for us to fully recover.
label: true_

sentences: But if we take the steps that I talked about today, then I know we will restore not just our home values, but also our common values.
label: true_

sentences: We’ll make owning a home a symbol of responsibility, not speculation -- a source of security for generations to come, just like it was for my grandparents.
label: true_

sentences: I want it to be just like that for all the young people who are here today and their children and their grandchildren.
label: true_

sentences: )And if we stay focused on middle-class security and opportunities to get into the middle class, if we take the strategy that I'm laying out for the entire economy -- for jobs and housing and education, health care, retirement, creating ladders of opportunity -- then we will secure that better bargain for all Americans, where hard work is once again rewarded with a shot at a middle-class life, which means more Americans will know the pride of that first paycheck.
label: true_

sentences: More Americans will know the satisfaction of flipping the sign to “Open” on their own business.
label: true_

sentences: More Americans will know the joy of scratching the child’s height on the door of their new home -- with pencil, of course.
label: true_

sentences: )We can do all this if we work together.
label: true_

sentences: And it won’t be easy.
label: true_

sentences: But if we take just a few bold steps -- and if Washington will just end the gridlock, set aside the slash-and-burn partisanship -- (applause) -- actually try to solve problems instead of scoring political points, our economy will grow stronger a year from now, five years from now, 10 years from now.
label: true_

sentences: )And as long as I've got the privilege to serve as your President, that's what I'm going to be fighting for.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: true_

sentences: It is --AUDIENCE MEMBER: We love you, Obama!THE PRESIDENT: I love you back.

sentences: It is good to be here.
label: non_check_worthy

sentences: Well, we are so glad to be here.
label: non_check_worthy

sentences: There he is right there.

sentences: God bless you.
